text: hi everyone pink that boy tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new metric
album formentera this is the eighth
full-length lp from indie rock and pop
veterans metric i know they've dropped a
couple of records recently but i i
didn't review them it's actually been
about a decade since i covered the
band's music in a formal focused review
i'm sorry but either way as i listen to
this new lp i am finding it to be an
interesting addition to their growing
catalog even if it does work some
familiar angles to that of 2018's art of
doubt which isn't necessarily a bad
thing because when that record dropped
it was one of the band's best in years
and easily one of their edgiest as well
there were a few tracks on there
especially die happy that had a
dystopian pop flare to them which is
essentially what foreman tara focuses on
for the entirety of the project but now
it seems like emily haynes and company
are taking things production wise in a
sleeker direction a synthetic direction
with spacious and sparkling production
that feels like almost the entire record
is set at night the resulting sound is
pretty cinematic and maybe inadvertently
a callback to classic indie rock
projects like uh interpol's turn on the
bright lights or even mgmt's oracular
spectacular on cuts that have more of a
pop edge such as false dichotomy but the
most striking thing about this lp is how
for metric it's it's very dark it's very
foreboding the coldness and the finality
and the eternity of a lot of the sounds
and lyrical themes on this lp are almost
too much to bear like with the opening
track doom scroller which is clearly
titled after a very recent cultural
phenomenon which i think the band
captures perfectly on this track not
only with miss haynes vocal sounding
pretty ominous but her lyrics read as
such as well over these really eerie edm
builds
and in the track i gotta say it lasts
ten minutes yes an opening song from
metric that lasts 10 whole minutes with
multiple phases and builds and shifts
and i actually found it to be really
engaging from front to back and it
somehow just fits the tone of the entire
record perfectly even if this is the
only track on the lp that sounds exactly
like this of course the themes of
digital dystopia on this track continue
on to subsequent songs like thinking of
someone who you'd like to be with while
the world is completely crumbling on the
track all comes crashing the
instrumental on this one is pretty much
everything you need nothing you don't
overdriven guitar leads airy synth
layers booming drums some very simple
and intimate vocal leads from miss
haynes from here we get the mesmerizing
what feels like eternity which does
spend quite a bit of time building up
tension but it is more than worth it
once the band hits you with this buzzing
hypnotic chorus with an earworm vocal
that is gonna be sticking with me for a
while feels like an eternity what feels
like an eternity plus add on to this the
unsettling verse is about being locked
into
a totally restless rat race that is
miserable and degrading and just wears
down on you next from here we have the
title track which is this my favorite
song is this my favorite tune on the
record no i don't necessarily feel like
this is
miss hayne's strongest and most
memorable vocal performance here but
what does move me about this track is
just how long expansive and how much of
a synth odyssey it feels like plus these
string sections that pop up here and
there are a beautiful touch too but yes
not my favorite song here but a lengthy
moment on the project i get kind of lost
in easily we do get a bit of a lull at
the midpoint of the record though
there's the hulking enemies of the ocean
with its huge and honking base notes
it's spaced out drums this track
unfortunately while it does pile the
sounds on high execution wise and groove
wise it doesn't really have the finesse
of many of the best tracks here
especially on the transition from the
verse to the chorus which just feels
like a clash i will never settle at its
core has more of a classic indie rock
formula i think at its base the song is
truly something that could have been on
any number of metric records prior but
it's produced and
dressed up in a way to where it feels
like it fits in aesthetically with
everything else here my one major issue
with the track is the vocal effects and
instrumental layering do feel weirdly
artificial in a way that
just isn't that pleasing to me even if
the record's purpose may be to present
something that sounds very fake or at
least like a little bit touched up but i
will say things do pick up toward the
end of the lp though false dichotomy i
think is one of metrics strongest songs
and singles in a long time like not only
are the beats and the synths just
popping but the lyrics do bring a pretty
smart take on you know this idea of
binary views of modern living and how
that's just like a farce oh please is a
really straightforward and groovy rocker
that pretty much sneaks a banger in
there before the record comes to a close
and paths in the sky while this may not
be my favorite tune on the lp just like
with the title track i do really like
what the song brings to the record
sonically because when it comes to the
instrumental side here this is easily
the warmest and most heavenly sounding
track on the entire lp when you dive
into the lyrics a little bit that's kind
of matched up with some sentiments of
you know being broken out of this uh rut
this emotional rut this personal ru so
you know the record does kind of end off
on a positive note does provide a ray of
light in the midst of all of this
darkness this track really does feel
like a dawn of a new day which again is
just a nice way to end things off and
yeah overall i thought this was a pretty
solid project i liked it quite a bit uh
this is the most enjoyable i found a
metric record to be in a while i liked
the consistent aesthetics across the lp
i like the lyrical themes and focus
across the record the songwriting for
the most part was really impressive on
most of the tracks here were there some
spots where
the vocals came off maybe a bit too
understated or the instrumental palettes
and performances uh just felt maybe too
mild a tad bit bland yes but i mean you
know metric has never been the most
aggressive band out there i kind of you
know got what i expected for the most
part going into this record as far as
delivery and attitude and energy level
but then beyond that the quality
songwriting and like i said the concepts
and the uh very digital and synthesis
across the record were a nice touch and
a nice surprise and yeah there were some
spots like the opener that i found to be
actually kind of surprising but overall
i really enjoyed this project i thought
it was really good and uh yeah i'm happy
i gave it a try i'm feeling a decent two
strong seven on this one tran position
